title: Experiences of Genetic Relatedness among Donor-Conceived Adults Sharing the same Sperm Donor.
abstractText:
Conventionally, it has been assumed to be best for all concerned that a sperm donor should remain unknown to any child subsequently born as a result of his donation. Although recently such practices have been challenged and - in some countries - reversed, little is known about the experiences of anonymous sperm donation for any of the parties personally involved.

This research study will provide a unique insight into donor conception through investigating, by means of email interviews, the experiences of a group of donor-conceived adults who have learned about their conception, discovered the identity of a previously-unknown donor, and have subsequently learned about, met and formed relationships with hitherto unknown genetic half-siblings who share the same donor but who live in different families - and indeed in different countries.

In addition, the study will also provide valuable information that can inform contemporary donor conception practices that share common features of :

  • favouring an open approach towards disclosure of the donorâ€™s identity to their offspring,
  • enabling the birth of several individuals sharing the same donor into a number of different families, 
  • permitting donor-conceived people to learn about and meet any genetic half-siblings sharing the same donor.
impactText: Citations in subsequent peer reviewed papers Healthcare Policy & public services
findingsText:
Key findings and outputs relate to: 

- description and critical analysis of policies regarding access to genetic and birth origins information for donor-conceived people in the UK in four distinct time periods, including the period during which participants in this study were conceived;

- tracking study participants' endeavours to trace their genetic heritage from the time of initial revelation of their donor-conceived status to the identification of their donor and location of donor half-siblings. Contribution to regulatory/policy consultations eg Parliament of Victoria Law Reform Committee (2011) Inquiry into access by donor_conceived people to information about donors, to which I gave written evidence (Submission No DCP 43) http://www.parliament.vic.gov.au/images/stories/committees/lawrefrom/iadcpiad/submissions/DCP43_-_Eric_Blyth.pdf
